text:
The rise of the "AQI Holiday": Why forests are becoming India's new luxury escapes
We used to pick weekend destinations based on mood; head to the hills for romance, beaches for fun, a hotel with a decent spa whenever we needed pampering. Today, however, our travel plans begin with a universal question: "How bad is the AQI there?"
Did you know the Air Quality Index (AQI) has quietly become India’s new travel influencer? Modern city dwellers are booking trips not for nightlife or infinity pools, but for one basic privilege: breathing without discomfort.
Fresh air has now replaced fancy rooms as the ultimate luxury. Here's why.
THE BIG BREATHING ESCAPE
Cities like Delhi and Mumbai now have a seasonal rhythm of respiratory panic where most mornings are masked, evenings are generally spent indoors, and cough syrups have replaced dessert. By the time Friday is here, there's a battle with fatigue, and by 7 pm we’re refreshing pollution maps, praying for a green patch on the screen that might offer refuge.
Enter the latest forest holiday trend; one where the tourism brochure doesn’t sell luxury, but promises something that is more basic: oxygen.
No wonder destinations like Tadoba and Gothangaon in Maharashtra have quietly become the new wellness getaways. Not the curated, scented-spa kind but the wild, grounding, lungs-opening-up kind.
Tadoba in Maharashtra, for instance, wasn’t always on the wellness map. It was a destination for wildlife purists, people who could tell a tiger by its whisker's pattern. However, these days, it hosts software engineers, advertising folks, tired parents, basically anyone whose chest has been feeling heavier than usual.
'LUXURY' HAS A NEW DEFINITION
Then there is the area around Gothangaon, on the fringes of Tadoba-Andhari Tiger Reserve. Here, luxury resorts are building an unexpected traveller profile: people who are exhausted from the simple act of living in the metros.
You do get the comforts of a premium holiday, including a plush bed, warm lighting, deep showers, but sans the city’s noise and hustle. You wake to the sound of koel calls bouncing off bamboo groves. Here breakfast includes millets and vegetables grown by communities in the buffer zones.
And your phone screen time drops, not because you’re trying, but because there is something far more compelling to look at: the horizon and the abundance of greenery.
TIGERS, YES. BUT ALSO THERAPY
Safaris (still) remain a big draw in Tadoba. Nothing can replace that heart-thudding anticipation of seeing stripes in the tall grass. But what’s interesting is what happens off the safari route.
Your nervous system, always on high alert in the city, begins to remember a different way of existing. Even your breath, shallow, rushed, unnoticeable, suddenly makes itself known.
Anupama Mukerjee Lohana, who leads restorative wellness programming at the Bamboo Forest Resort & Spa at Tadoba, sees this transformation every single day. “People arrive with phones buzzing and minds racing,” she says. “By day two, their bodies have slowed down on their own, shoulders loosen, sleep deepens. The forest doesn’t ask you to relax. It makes you relax.”
There’s a quiet confidence in the way she says it... like she’s watched the wild heal hundreds of strangers without ceremony or effort.
She explains it further: “Tadoba’s bamboo and dry deciduous forests offer softer light, cleaner air and a rare quietude. At the retreats, one set along the Irai backwaters in Gothangaon and another on Tadoba’s wild edge, we integrate simple Ayurvedic routines and mindful food into the guest experience, allowing the forest itself to become a scientifically grounded healing space.”
TRAVEL AS PREVENTIVE HEALTHCARE
We’ve reached a striking cultural moment where travel isn’t just leisure any more. It’s maintenance, strategy and survival all rolled into one experience.
Doctors talk openly now about the health consequences of chronic exposure to polluted air (inflammation, anxiety, fatigue, falling immunity). In response, urban Indians are putting nature back into their self-care routine. In essence, a forest holiday has shifted from being an indulgence to being a sane choice.
You ask what's the "Best Part"? The fact that you come back with a different sort of souvenir.
We may not always acknowledge it, but the human body is homesick for trees, for silence, for darkness that isn’t neon, for skies that aren’t filtered by dust. By choosing forests over malls, and canopies made of bamboo over loud rooftop bars, we’re responding to a need that is deeper than wanderlust.
We’re choosing wellness over convenience and life over survival. And maybe that’s why the AQI holiday is quickly becoming India’s favourite escape. Sometimes the most profound luxury is simply the ability to breathe clean air.
